importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: This is the date of the CNN article's update, indicating when the issue of limited VA therapy sessions was reported and widely discussed in media.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The policy shift to limit one-on-one therapy sessions began around 2021 under new VA leadership, particularly after Doug Collins became VA secretary in January 2021, marking a significant period of change in VA mental health care delivery.

keyTakeAways: VA therapists and patients report that one-on-one therapy sessions are being abruptly ended, even when patients have chronic conditions like PTSD requiring long-term care.
The policy to limit therapy sessions was introduced under the Trump administration and intensified after Doug Collins became VA secretary in 2021.
Providers report that they are now required to justify extending therapy sessions in writing, and face disciplinary consequences for resisting the policy.
Veterans with long-standing mental health issues, such as PTSD, feel abandoned and re-traumatized when therapy is cut off prematurely.
The American Psychological Association has expressed concern and is investigating reports of inappropriate therapy limits.
Many veterans express discomfort with alternatives like group therapy, especially those who have built deep trust with their current therapist.
There is growing concern that such policies may undermine recovery, increase veteran suicide risk, and contribute to a worsening staff shortage in VA mental health services.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Veterans seeking long-term mental health care through the VA are facing significant disruptions due to a new policy that limits one-on-one therapy sessions, especially after Doug Collins became VA secretary in 2021. Veterans like Michael, a combat veteran with PTSD, report being abruptly cut off from therapy, even when they need ongoing treatment. Providers say the policy is not clinically appropriate, as many mental health conditions, including PTSD, are chronic and require long-term care. Some providers have been disciplined or forced to justify session extensions in writing, leading to staff shortages and resignations. While the VA claims there are no session limits and that care is personalized, patients and clinicians argue that the policy undermines trust, recovery, and patient autonomy. The American Psychological Association is reviewing the issue, and veterans express fear that their mental health is being compromised by premature termination of care.
title: VA Therapy Sessions Being Limited, Veterans Say, Sparking Outrage
